summary: This is a court order from Judge Kenneth A. Marra denying Jeffrey Epstein's motion to file his reply brief under seal in the civil case Jane Doe No. 2 v. Jeffrey Epstein. The court cites the public's right to access judicial records and notes that details of the agreement between Epstein and the U.S. Attorney have largely already been unsealed.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Defendant in the civil case Jane Doe No. 2 v. Jeffrey Epstein; filed a motion to seal his reply brief citing a confidentiality clause in an agreement with the U.S. Attorney.

persons.name: Jane Doe No. 2
persons.context: Plaintiff in the civil lawsuit against Jeffrey Epstein; identified pseudonymously.

persons.name: Kenneth A. Marra
persons.context: Issued the order denying Epstein's motion to seal, citing local rules and case law on public access to court records.

connections.description: Plaintiff (Jane Doe No. 2) is suing defendant (Epstein) in a civil case, indicating an alleged victim-perpetrator relationship central to the litigation.
Epstein cites a confidentiality clause in an agreement with the U.S. Attorney as the reason to seal documents; the U.S. Attorney had objected to unsealing parts of the agreement.

events.title: Epstein files Motion to Seal
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein files a motion to file his reply to his Motion to Stay under seal, citing a confidentiality agreement with the U.S. Attorney.

events.title: Court denies Motion to Seal
events.description: Judge Kenneth A. Marra issues an order denying Epstein's motion to seal, ordering docket entries 29 and 30 to be unsealed for public inspection.

events.title: U.S. Attorney's objections in related case
events.description: The U.S. Attorney objects to unsealing any part of an agreement with Epstein in the case In re: Jane Doe, No. 08-80736-CIV, as referenced by the court.

locations: United States District Court, Southern District of Florida
West Palm Beach, Palm Beach County, Florida
Clerk's Office in West Palm Beach, Florida
keyFacts: The court denied Jeffrey Epstein's motion to seal his reply brief, reinforcing the principle of public access to court records.
Epstein sought to seal the document to comply with a confidentiality clause in an agreement between him and the U.S. Attorney.
The court noted that details of the agreement had largely already been unsealed and released to the public.
The order specifically unsealed docket entries 29 and 30 for public inspection via CM/ECF.
The document references a related case, In re: Jane Doe, No. 08-80736-CIV, where the U.S. Attorney objected to unsealing parts of an agreement.
